G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and other applicable Massachusetts landlord‑tenant statutes.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This action is brought in the Chelsea Division of the District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, as the Premises are located in Chelsea, Suffolk County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 185C.proposition: This action is brought in the Chelsea Division of the District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, as the Premises are located in Chelsea, Suffolk County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court because the rental property that is the subject of this action is located in Chelsea, Massachusetts, and the acts and omissions complained of occurred there. See G.L. c. 223, § 2.

*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..raw_text: *King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass. 658, 660–61 (1977)
*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..proposition: Defendant, as landlord, retains control over the common areas of the building at 45 Washington Avenue, including the main entry door, hallways, basement, and shared access areas. See *King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass. 658, 660–61 (1977) (landlord retains control over common areas).
*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..case_name: King v. G & M REALTY CORP.
*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..support_reasoning: The case does involve a landlord’s duty regarding a common stairway, but it does not say anything about 45 Washington Avenue or about specific building components like the main entry door, hallways, basement, or shared access areas in that building. It is cited properly only for the general rule that a landlord who retains control over common areas owes a duty of reasonable care; using it to assert that this particular defendant retained control of particular areas at a different address is inaccurate. The proposition misuses the citation for a factual control point rather than the general legal principle the case establishes.
*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “With respect to areas retained in the landlord’s control, the landlord may be viewed as in effect an ‘occupier.’ … We think the measure of the landlord’s responsibility to the tenant with respect to common areas left in the landlord’s control should not differ in kind from that owed by the landlord to the tenant’s visitors.”

*Winchester v. O\u2019Brien*, 266 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential tenancy includes a covenant of quiet enjoyment, whether or not expressly stated in a written lease. See G.L. c. 186, § 14; *Winchester v. O’Brien*, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929).
*Winchester v. O\u2019Brien*, 266 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses an implied right of the tenant to beneficial and peaceful enjoyment arising from the lease (“the lease carried with it an implication…”), but it does not state that *every residential tenancy* includes a covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor that such a covenant exists by virtue of statute (G.L. c. 186, § 14). The case is framed in terms of implied obligations and tort/nuisance principles rather than a universal, statutory covenant in all residential tenancies. Thus it provides background support for implied quiet enjoyment duties, but not for the specific, broad statutory proposition claimed.
*Winchester v. O\u2019Brien*, 266 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The ‘grant of any thing carries an implication, that the grantee shall have all that is necessary to the enjoyment of the grant, so far as the grantor has power to give it.’ … The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … The same act may be a breach of the covenant for quiet enjoyment and also a wrong causing injury to the tenant for which injunctive relief might be sought or an action of tort would lie.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants against serious interferences with their use and enjoyment of the leased premises caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102–04 (1982); *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 715–18 (1977).
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.support_reasoning: The court explicitly explains the meaning of “quiet enjoyment” in landlord‑tenant law as protecting tenants from serious interferences with their tenancy caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions, and ties § 14’s “quiet enjoyment” language to that common-law covenant. It cites Blackett and other cases and describes quiet enjoyment as freedom from substantial interference that impairs the character and value of the leased premises, thereby directly supporting the stated proposition.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977). Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.” *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. at 102.

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants against serious interferences with their use and enjoyment of the leased premises caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102–04 (1982); *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 715–18 (1977).
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that the landlord’s implied covenant of quiet enjoyment is violated where tenants are “very substantially deprived” of quiet enjoyment due to serious interference (here, loud bar noise) that is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted, and that was within the landlord’s control. The court emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct (acts or omissions), not intent, is controlling, and affirms constructive eviction based on such interference, matching the proposition stated.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.proposition: A landlord’s failure to remedy defective or unsafe conditions in areas under the landlord’s control, after notice, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where the conditions substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises. See *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850–51 (1997); *Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744, 747–49 (2005).
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses what level of landlord fault is required for a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment and uses as examples a landlord’s failure to repair known defects. The court states that § 14 liability requires at least negligent conduct, and expressly notes that a landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises has frequently been deemed a violation of § 14, which fits the proposition that failure to remedy defective/unsafe conditions after notice can constitute such a breach when they substantially interfere with use and enjoyment.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.relevant_excerpt: “Twelve years later, in Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, supra, we rejected a claim that a violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, could be imposed only if it were proved that a landlord was reckless in disregarding his tenant’s rights, and we concluded that negligent conduct, conduct involving ‘some degree of fault,’ by a landlord could support the imposition of liability under § 14. Id. at 789. We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’”

*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: A landlord’s failure to remedy defective or unsafe conditions in areas under the landlord’s control, after notice, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where the conditions substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises. See *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850–51 (1997); *Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744, 747–49 (2005).
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment and notes that a landlord generally must have notice and act at least negligently in failing to alleviate a condition, citing Al‑Ziab. However, the court holds that there was no breach here because the landlord acted immediately and remedied the conditions, and expressly finds no interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. Thus, Jablonski does not stand for the proposition that failure to remedy after notice can constitute a breach; it applies the standard but finds it unmet.
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt:
We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Authy., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994). Generally, the landlord must have had notice of the condition interfering with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises, and he must have at least acted negligently in not alleviating the condition. See Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850-851 (1997).

Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions... We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 15.proposition: Common entrances, hallways, stairways, and basements of multi-unit residential buildings are areas typically retained under the landlord’s control and for which the landlord owes duties of care and maintenance. See *King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass. 658, 660–61 (1977); see also G.L. c. 186, § 15.

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: A landlord may be held liable for breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 where the landlord, or one under his control, fails to correct conditions that interfere with the tenant’s use of the premises, even when the immediate acts (such as theft or intrusion) are committed by third parties, if such interference is the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s failure to act. See *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. at 717–18; *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196, 201–03 (1979).
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: Berman concerns strict landlord liability and rent abatement for loss of heat and hot water under the implied warranty of habitability, not liability for breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 or for third‑party criminal acts. The opinion does not discuss § 14, quiet enjoyment, third‑party intrusions, or the ‘natural and probable consequence’ framework used in Blackett. It therefore does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated and is being cited beyond its actual holding and reasoning.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “The landlord relies in part on case law relating to tort liability for injuries caused by failure to repair defective premises. We have held that, when the defect occurs in the common areas, the landlord is subject to a duty of reasonable care. King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658, 661-662 (1977). When the defect occurs in the rented premises, the question is not one of negligence, but one of breach of warranty. In the latter instance, the landlord must comply at least with minimum standards prescribed by the State building and sanitary codes.”

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 277–79 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that serious security and safety issues, including unlawful entry and threats to the tenant’s safety arising from a landlord’s failure to maintain common areas, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g., *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 277–79 (1994) (landlord’s failure to provide reasonable security measures may result in liability where foreseeable harm results); *Lipsitt v. Plaud*, 466 Mass. 240, 246–48 (2013) (recognizing scope of landlord duties and statutory protections for tenants).
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that pervasive criminal activity and resulting safety threats in common areas, combined with the landlord’s failure to take reasonable measures within its control (such as using statutory mechanisms to exclude dangerous non‑tenants), can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court explains that if tenants effectively lose the use of common areas due to such conditions, and this is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord failed to do, the landlord may be liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14. That aligns with the proposition that serious safety and security problems arising from failure to maintain/common‑area security can breach quiet enjoyment.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development… then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises… If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Lipsitt v. Plaud*, 466 Mass. 240, 246\u.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that serious security and safety issues, including unlawful entry and threats to the tenant’s safety arising from a landlord’s failure to maintain common areas, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g., *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 277–79 (1994) (landlord’s failure to provide reasonable security measures may result in liability where foreseeable harm results); *Lipsitt v. Plaud*, 466 Mass. 240, 246–48 (2013) (recognizing scope of landlord duties and statutory protections for tenants).
*Lipsitt v. Plaud*, 466 Mass. 240, 246\u.support_reasoning: Lipsitt v. Plaud concerns whether the Massachusetts Wage Act preempts common-law contract and quasi-contract claims for unpaid wages, and secondarily addresses veil piercing. It does not discuss landlord-tenant law, common areas, security, safety, unlawful entry, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Citing Lipsitt for the scope of landlord duties or quiet enjoyment is therefore inaccurate; it provides no authority on those issues.
*Lipsitt v. Plaud*, 466 Mass. 240, 246\u.relevant_excerpt: "In this case, we are asked to decide whether G. L. c. 149, §§ 148 and 150 (Wage Act), are intended to be the exclusive remedy for the recovery of unpaid wages under Massachusetts law, preempting common-law breach of contract and related quasi-contract claims. We conclude that they are not."

G.L. c. 143, \u00a7 3.proposition: Defendant has also violated his statutory duty not to interfere with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment by failing to maintain the building in compliance with applicable safety and building standards, including those requiring that egress doors and means of egress be properly maintained and secured. See G.L. c. 186, § 14; G.L. c. 143, § 3; G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L (State Sanitary Code).

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: Defendant has also violated his statutory duty not to interfere with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment by failing to maintain the building in compliance with applicable safety and building standards, including those requiring that egress doors and means of egress be properly maintained and secured. See G.L. c. 186, § 14; G.L. c. 143, § 3; G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L (State Sanitary Code).

*Crowell v. McCaffrey*, 377 Mass. 443, 4.proposition: A violation of the State Sanitary Code may be evidence of a serious interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment and breach of the landlord’s obligations under G.L. c. 186, § 14. See *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. at 201–03; *Crowell v. McCaffrey*, 377 Mass. 443, 451–52 (1979).
*Crowell v. McCaffrey*, 377 Mass. 443, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that there is an implied agreement that the rented unit complies with minimum standards prescribed by building and sanitary codes and that violations of those codes are relevant to the landlord’s obligations. While Crowell is framed in terms of negligence and implied warranty rather than explicitly under G.L. c. 186, § 14, it clearly treats State Sanitary Code violations as evidence of a breach of the landlord’s statutory/warranty obligations toward the tenant. This aligns with using such violations as evidence of a serious interference with quiet enjoyment and breach of landlord obligations under c. 186, § 14.
*Crowell v. McCaffrey*, 377 Mass. 443, 4.relevant_excerpt: “We now find in the rental of a dwelling unit, without regard to length of term or presence or absence of furniture, an implied agreement by the landlord that the rented unit complies with the minimum standards prescribed by building and sanitary codes and that he will do whatever those codes require for compliance during the term of the renting. That agreement extended to the porch if the porch was part of the rented unit.… The relevant provisions of the codes should have been placed before the jury.” (377 Mass. at 451–52).
